8.play: KING HENRY IV: Had been alive this hour,

9.play: KING HENRY IV: If like a Christian thou hadst truly borne

10.play: KING HENRY IV: Betwixt our armies true intelligence.

11.play: EARL OF WORCESTER: What I have done my safety urged me to;

12.play: EARL OF WORCESTER: And I embrace this fortune patiently,

13.play: EARL OF WORCESTER: Since not to be avoided it falls on me.

14.play: KING HENRY IV: Bear Worcester to the death and Vernon too:

15.play: KING HENRY IV: Other offenders we will pause upon.

16.play: KING HENRY IV: How goes the field?

17.play: PRINCE HENRY: The noble Scot, Lord Douglas, when he saw

18.play: PRINCE HENRY: The fortune of the day quite turn'd from him,

19.play: PRINCE HENRY: The noble Percy slain, and all his men

20.play: PRINCE HENRY: Upon the foot of fear, fled with the rest;

21.play: PRINCE HENRY: And falling from a hill, he was so bruised

22.play: PRINCE HENRY: That the pursuers took him. At my tent

23.play: PRINCE HENRY: The Douglas is; and I beseech your grace

24.play: PRINCE HENRY: I may dispose of him.

25.play: KING HENRY IV: With all my heart.

26.play: PRINCE HENRY: Then, brother John of Lancaster, to you

28.play: This honourable bounty shall belong: Go to the Douglas, and deliver him

29.play: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free:

30.play: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free: His valour shown upon our crests to-day

31.play: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free: Hath taught us how to cherish such high deeds

32.play: Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free: Even in the bosom of our adversaries.

33.play: LANCASTER: I thank your grace for this high courtesy,

34.play: LANCASTER: Which I shall give away immediately.
